channel.title: Posts on A minimal Hugo website
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on A minimal Hugo website

item.title: Handbook of Statistical Analyses Using R
item.description: 1 Chapter 1 - Introduction to R 1.1 Import the Dataset 1.1.1 .csv File 1.1.2 .xlsx File 1.1.3 .rda Files 1.2 Export the Dataset 1.3 Get the Meta-data of the Dataset 1.4 Simple Summary Statistics 1 Chapter 1 - Introduction to R 1.1 Import the Dataset 1.1.1 .csv File # Method 1: data("Forbes2000", package = "HSAUR3") # Method 2: #csvForbes2000 <- read.table("Forbes2000.csv",header = TRUE, sep = ",", row.

item.title: R Notebook
item.description: 1 R Setup 101 1.1 R Packages for Basic R Installation or Update 1.2 Read SAS sas7bdat data into R 1.2.1 Use library sas7bdat in R 1.2.2 Use library haven package in R 1.2.3 Load Data files in R Studio 2 Create a Website using RMarkdown 2.1 RMarkdown, Hugo, Netlify 2.2 Blogdown & Hugo - Fix ToC (with Rmd) 3 Write a Reproducible Paper using RMarkdown 3.

item.title: Statistical Learning
item.description: 1 Little Statistical Learning Book 1.1 Model Representation: a function \(h : X → Y\) 1.2 Linear Algebra Review 2 ML Resources 2.1 Superb Online Courses and Books 2.2 Other Resources 1 Little Statistical Learning Book 1.1 Model Representation: a function \(h : X → Y\) This function \(h\) is called a hypothesis. Accuracy of our hypothesis function \(h\) is measured using a cost/loss function.

item.title: SAS Notebook
item.description: 1 My Little SAS Book 1.1 Using PROC SORT to remove duplicates 1.2 Input() and put() for variable type conversion 1.3 Merging/Stacking Datasets – Truncated Values 1 My Little SAS Book The aim is to document code chunks that are likely to be re-used for fast searching and indexing. 1.1 Using PROC SORT to remove duplicates There are three options that might be helpful: DUPOUT=, NODUPRECS, and NODUPKEYS.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This sample post is mainly for blogdown users. If you do not use blogdown, you can skip the first section. 1. Markdown or R Markdown This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
